-------- Original Message --------

Aloha Lucas!

I read Amir's response and agree with what he said; here are some ideas I
have as well.

Keep your resume short, to one page. When you are applying for a specific
position, make sure you put all the relevant qualifications you have that
match the job description in the top quarter of the resume - that makes
it as easy as possible for HR people to see that you match the job and
will put it in the "keep for consideration" pile.

Definitely mention self-taught education. It may actually be easier to
put all your skills on your resume, and then mention in your cover letter
what is self-taught and what is formal education. Also mention other
volunteer involvements with the industry, such as being a Conference
Associate at the GDC, any other clubs you belong to like IGDA or
SIGGRAPH.

I put together several documents for my job interviews: Cover Letter,
Resume, Work History, Education History, References. Also, because I have
done a lot of work through temporary agencies, I have a separate
Temporary Work History to show specific companies I have worked for and
the assignments I did. For my first contact with a company I just use the
Cover Letter and Resume. At the bottom of the Resume and in the text of
the Cover Letter I indicate that I have a complete Work History,
Education History and References available upon request. When I actually
get to filling out an application, I use the Work History, Education
History and References - I have found that most of the time I am given
the application in the waiting room for the 15 minutes before the
interview. This is never enough time to complete the application, and not
all the information is in my memory. And the application usually has
impossibly small spaces for the information. Often the application says,
"If you need additional space, attach to the application." So, it is much
easier to have all that information already typed up and simply attach
it.

In my Resume I only have my RELEVANT work experience, usually listed in
the order of greatest relevance towards the top (even if it is not my
most recent job). The Work History has all my jobs in reverse
chronological order (most recent first all the way to my first job as a
teenager). This makes the Resume easier to read and relate to the job I
am applying for. I do a similar thing with my Education History, simply
listing relevant education on the Resume, then a detailed list on the
separate Education History (this is where I list my self-taught stuff as
well).

If possible, while you are researching the company, see if there are any
resumes online for the people you plan to work with. Some company
websites have links between the name of the employee and the person's
resume/website. This can give you an idea of what they like to see in a
resume based on what they put in their own resume and how they like to
see it.

And like Amir said: Network, network, network. This is the single most
successful way that people get jobs, better than newspaper ads, job
agencies, online job websites, etc. I also would recommend the book,
"What Color is Your Parachute" for any job search.

Good Luck!

Mahalo :-)
